context: The abundance of the halogenated VOCs in the exhaled breath of CKD was comparable to that found in the control rats, thus excluding the effect of CKD on the breath content of these products.Comparison of VOCs in exhaled breath and fecal gas emissions Numerous VOCs detected in the exhaled breath of both normal and CKD animals were also present in emissions from their cultured feces. This suggests that the shared VOCs are in part generated by the gut microbial flora, absorbed in the circulation and released in the lungs. It should be noted that the four VOCs which were significantly different in the exhaled breath of CKD animals (i.e. isoprene, pentanal, hexanal, and heptanal) did not overlap with the four significantly different VOCs emitted from their cultured feces (i.e. DMDS, DMTS, C3H6OS, and C5H10OS). This observation excludes the possibility that the differences observed in the exhaled breath VOCs between the CKD and control animals were caused by defecation within the chamber. The study revealed the presence of 56 VOCs in the exhaled breath at different concentrations when compared to the air used to flush the glass chamber, and 36 VOCs released from the cultured stools in the rats.
